yes it's a claim, but has relatively more history to back it up than, say, the LDS claim to be a continuation of the early church
The claim that it's a continuation of the original church would be disputed by a lot of people -- f'rinstance, Protestants who believe in a "Great Apostacy"; distinctions --> distinctives

When writing about a term rather than using the term to write about what it refers to, italicize it. The phrase "... refers to ..." indicates that. See [[Wikipedia:Manual of Style]].
/* The Church within the Empire */ added death of Petros VII
I doubt that the Church of Constantinople is the oldest Eastern Orthodox church. By one account, that city was not a patriachal seat until it assumed political importance in the Byzantine Empire.
I've revised the first sentence so that the Style Manual would not require italics, since it's about the thing rather than about the phrase. I don't know if this will make David Gerard happy.
